BETTER. BROADCASTS .NEWS LETTER
THREE
INDICATOR OF OPINION
One method of alerting thought about
radio-TV programs, preparatory to the
Look-Listen Project, is being tried by the
Wisconsin Association for Better Radio and
Television—the Indicator of Opinion.
We reprint it for those who wish to use
it. Copies of it may be made for use in
groups. In sending results to ACBB Head¬
quarters, 423 N. Pinckney, Madison, Wis.,
please send in the number of Yeses and
Noes for each question—not merely the re¬
port of the majority vote. And please send
in a report if your group uses the Indicator,
won’t you?
The PURPOSE of the Indicator is to
give listeners a few interesting and definite
points to consider before taking part in the
Look-Listen Project (that Project being our
important undertaking); also to inform
broadcasters and sponsors of these opin¬
ions.
A. NEWS
1. Do you know what preparation news
commentators have for weighing the im¬
portance of news? For instance:
Has your favorite commentator, .,
a) a college education? Yes.... No....
b) extensive foreign travel? Yes.... No....
c) experience on a newspaper noted for
giving both sides of questions? Yes.... No....
2. Do you hear news commentary which
gives you a clear understanding of other
nations’ points of view when they differ
from that of the U.S.? Yes.... No. If so,
Program . Time.
3. a) Do you ask yourself, when a
newsman presents one side of a question,
whether there is another side? Yes....No.
b) In the last month, have you sought
the other side by:
1. listening to a commentator who is
impartial or who has a different slant?
Yes.... No.....
2. reading a newspaper or magazine
with a different slant? Yes.... No.—
B. PLAYS
1. a) Do dramas of family life have
always to be funny to be entertaining?
Yes.... No. Or does occasional anxiety
over some member of the family hold your
interest? Yes.... No.
2. Should violence or the threat of vio¬
lence be the only (or even the main) ele¬
ment of interest in a play for children?
Yes.... No. Or for adults? Yes.... No.
3. Do most broadcast plays you hear
reveal greatness of spirit in the hero? Yes....
No. Or merely his getting what he
wants for himself (girl, money, position)?
Yes.... No.

D. ADVERTISING
1. Do you buy products advertised on
TV or radio because of the advertising?
(check one): a—Often .... b—Occasionally
.... c—Almost never .....
2. If you buy because of broadcast ad¬
vertising what entices you to do so:
a) Information about new products or
new features? ....
b) Information about other people’s us¬
ing it? ....
c) Information about the producer’s de¬
velopment or good policies? ....
d) Repetition of name or advertising
slogan, only? ....
3. Within a month have you been de¬
terred from purchasing a product by broad¬
cast commercials that are:
a) long ....; b) loud ....; c) repetitious ....;
d) inserted as extra advertising between
two programs ....; e) interrupting program
every five minutes? ....
4. When shopping, do you say you are
buying (or not buying) a product because
of the quality of the program or of the ad¬
vertising? Yes_ No.
E. GOOD TASTE AND
GOOD MANNERS
1. Is national and world solidarity
helped by jokes which ridicule a whole
class (Negroes, Englishmen, mothers-in-
law, Baptists, etc.)? Yes.... No.
2. Do you consider it: constructive ....;
destructive .... to overstate the power and
goodness of our country: e.g. introducing
the president of the U.S. as the “first citizen
of the world”; calling ours "the most gen¬
erous nation on earth”? Yes.... No.
3. Do you find some early evening TV
programs are are not suitable for the whole
family? Plays of family situation? Yes....
No. Mysteries? Yes.... No.
F. CHILDREN’S PROGRAMS
1. Is there sufficient variety in programs
for children? Yes.... No.
2. Are constructive programs of music....,
adventure...., information...., readily avail¬
able to children aged 8-13? Yes.... No.
3. Do most children’s programs promote
desirable standards of conduct? Yes.... No.
Or do they glorify undesirable types of be¬
havior? Yes.... No.
4. Within the month have you listened
to programs intended for children: often ....;
three times or more ....; once not at
all .
Program Trends, 1954-55
In television the trend is toward longer
programs, the expense being met by alter¬
nating or multiple sponsorship. ABC al¬
ready has scheduled four hour-long dramas.
Center Stage, which alternated with U.S.
Steel Hour this summer, changes its name
to Elgin Hour—but not its quality, Tues¬
day, 9:30-10:30 p.m. EST. Kraft Theater
wijll appear Wed. 9:00 p.m. on NBC;
Thursday, 9:30 p.m. on ABC. Lux Theater
will be seen Thursday at 10:00 p.m. on NBC.
Disneyland, ABC, 7:30-8:30 p.m. Wednes¬
days, is a full hour show.
The advantages of the ninety-minute
presentation have been demonstrated by
“Omnibus,” a very popular program last
year. It returns to CBS-TV, Sunday, Octo¬
ber 17.
NBC will feature several “spectaculars’,
most of them ninety minutes long. The first
of these is a two-hour presentation of “Mac¬
beth” with Maurice Evans, sponsored by
Hallmark. With this emphasis on big shows,
networks are vying with each other for well
known artists and producers.
Firestone, 7:30 Mondays on ABC;
LOOK AND LISTEN
Look and listen and tell what you think.
It’s simple, effective. It is the method of the
Look-Listen Project, the one undertaking
of this year in which all groups cooperating
in the American Council for Better Broad¬
casts will urge their members to take part.
Each person is asked to listen to eight
programs on one network between 3-10
p.m. and check them as good, excellent,
mediocre, or poor, and tell why they
checked as they did. The overall report,
summarizing all these individual reports is
sent to broadcasters, sponsors, and the Fed¬
eral Communications Commission which
licenses stations. Because sponsors and
broadcasters are asking themselves (in
early spring especially) what changes to
make in programs, it is necessary to get in¬
dividual reports to Headquarters by JAN¬
UARY 31.
Many, many reports are necessary for
maximum "eflecl of the Piujecl. Those con¬
trolling programs would like to know, if
possible, what everybody thinks of their
programs. The nearer the Project comes to
being a total report, the more influential it
is.
The Project is also helpful to those who
report. One needs to know what he wants
if he is to get it. One can’t think what it is
he likes and does not like about a program
without becoming more sure what it is that
he wants.
This project is not like the surveys of
commercial rating bureaus; for it emphasizes
opinions of programs. It is complementary to
them.
It is the chance for people to attend to
their business. The air waves belong to the
people. They are responsible for expressing
themselves on what is being done with them.
The first step in taking part in the project
is to get supplies. They are sent without
cost except the cards, which are three cents
per person. However, you belong to some
local group which would probably want to
have a part in helping this project. If it
and ten of its members join ACBB, cards
for as many as thirty participants will be
sent without charge. Dues are nominal; so
this should not be difficult. Each member
gets five copies a year of the Newsletter.
Send for material to Mrs. G. F. Matthews,
4539 Winnequah Road, Madison, Wis., in
plenty of time so that you will have every¬
thing by early January, or before.
INFORMATION FOR TEACHERS
A special 24-page section of Scholastic
Teacher for October 6 will be devoted to
new TV and radio programs having some
merit for schools.
“Listenables and Lookables” is now be¬
coming a regular weekly service in all teach¬
er editions of Scholastic Magazines.
For NEWS and GETTING ACQUAINT¬
ED WITH PEOPLE, PLACES, AND
THINGS, Edward R. Murrow is back on
CBS with “See It Now” Tuesday at 10:30
and “Person to Person” Friday at 10:30;
and will have a program for young people
in the manner of “Person to Person.” It will
consist of interviews of young people and
will be called “Youngsters.”
Sunday afternoon is especially strong in
programs of general information on most
of the networks.
MUSIC is all but absent from television.
